description: From Middle English whippen, wippen (“to flap violently”), from Middle Dutch wippen (“to swing, leap, dance, oscillate”) and Middle Low German wippen (“to move quickly”), from Proto-Germanic *wipjaną (“to move back and forth”). Some similarity to Sanskrit root वेप् (vep, “shake, flourish”), Latin vibrō (“I shake”). (See Swedish vippa and Danish vippe (“to shake”)).
The unetymological wh- is probably expressive of the sound of a whip; compare the same development in whisk and onomatopoeias such as whack and whoosh.
The political senses are from whipper-in (“huntsman who keeps the hounds from wandering”), 18th century hunting terminology.

definitionGroups.group: A lash; a pliant, flexible instrument, such as a rod (commonly of cane or rattan) or a plaited or braided rope or thong (commonly of leather) used to create a sharp "crack" sound for directing or herding animals.

entries.meaning: The same instrument used to strike a person or animal for corporal punishment or torture.
examples: Once he ran out of appeals, he knew he would soon feel the sting of the whip.

entries.meaning: A blow administered with a whip.
examples: I had hardly said the word, when Kit jumped into the saddle, and gave his horse a whip and a spur — and off it cantered, as if it were in as great a hurry to be married as Kit himself.

entries.meaning: (hunting) A whipper-in.
examples: From the far side of the wood came the long shrill screech  […]  which signifies that one of the whips has viewed the fox quitting the covert.

entries.meaning: (politics) A member of a political party who is in charge of enforcing the party's policies in votes; a whipper-in.
examples: I was going to vote against the bill, but the party whip came to see me and made it clear I needed to vote for it.

entries.meaning: (UK politics, with definite article) A document distributed weekly to MPs by party whips informing them of upcoming votes in parliament.
(UK politics, by extension) The regular status of an MP within a parliamentary party, which can be revoked by the party as a disciplinary measure.
examples: to withdraw the whip

entries.meaning: Whipped cream.
examples: Did you want to add some whip to your coffee, ma'am?

entries.meaning: (nautical) A purchase in which one block is used to gain a 2:1 mechanical advantage.
(African-American Vernacular, MTE) A mode of personal motorized transportation; an automobile, all makes and models including motorcycles, excluding public transportation.
examples: Big whip I'm underground parking

entries.meaning: (roller derby) A move in which one player transfers momentum to another.
examples: Hyponym: hip whip

entries.meaning: A whipping motion; a thrashing about.
examples: I was startled by the whip of the rope when it finally snapped.

entries.meaning: The quality of being whiplike or flexible; suppleness, as of the shaft of a golf club.

definitionGroups.group: Any of various pieces that operate with a quick vibratory motion

entries.meaning: A spring in certain electrical devices for making a circuit
(music) A wippen, a rocking component in certain piano actions.
(historical) A coach driver; a coachman.
examples: Lord Carington  […]  led the way with his chestnuts, having a distinguished brother whip, Lord Londesborough, by his side.

verbs.description: whip (third-person singular simple present whips, present participle whipping, simple past and past participle whipped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To hit with a whip.
examples: The rider whipped the horse.

entries.meaning: (transitive, by extension) To hit with any flexible object.
examples: I whipped her with a newspaper.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To defeat, as in a contest or game.
(transitive) To mix in a rapid aerating fashion, especially food.
examples: to whip eggs or cream

entries.meaning: (transitive) To urge into action or obedience.
examples: He whipped the department into shape.

entries.meaning: (transitive, politics) To enforce a member voting in accordance with party policy.
(transitive, nautical) To bind the end of a rope with twine or other small stuff to prevent its unlaying: fraying or unravelling.
examples: Its string  […] is firmly whipt about with small Gut

entries.meaning: (transitive, nautical) To hoist or purchase by means of a whip.
To sew lightly; specifically, to form (a fabric) into gathers by loosely overcasting the rolled edge and drawing up the thread.
examples: to whip a ruffle

entries.meaning: (transitive) To throw or kick an object at a high velocity.
examples: He whipped the ball at me.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To fish a body of water especially by making repeated casts.
examples: whipping its rough surface for a trout

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To snap back and forth like a whip.
examples: The pennants whipped in the wind.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move very fast.
examples: The wind whipped through the valley.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To move (something) very fast; often with up, out, etc.
examples: He whips out his pocketbook every moment, and writes descriptions of everything he sees.

entries.meaning: (transitive, roller derby) To transfer momentum from one skater to another.
(figurative) To lash with sarcasm, abuse, etc.
To thrash; to beat out, as grain, by striking.
examples: to whip wheat
